course.subject: FINA
course.name: Mergers, Acquisitions, and Corporate Restructuring
course.description: This course analyzes mechanisms underlying the creation of value in mergers, acquisitions and corporate restructuring. Students will learn analytical techniques and tools to analyze (a) strategy behind corporate restructuring transactions, whether and what to acquire, (b) evaluation and financing of acquisitions, and (c) decisions and processes that impact value creation in mergers.

reviews.author: smellsshit
reviews.title: Well taught course with good grading
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers basic concepts of how an M&A deal works, it also covers LBO.

The concepts are quite straightforward and easy to understand and do not require valuation knowledge beyond FINA3103.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Marvin is a nice professor and willing to engage students during the class and answer any questions you have.

The only thing about this fantastic professor is his voice, sometimes cannot hear him clearly in the back, and his tone will be too dry for a 3-hour lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite good.

1. Final Exam (Individual) 30%
2. “Shark Tank” Project Report & Presentation (Group) 40%
Project Report 20%
Project Presentation 20%
3. Case Assignment (Individual) 10%
4. Class Participation (Individual) 10%
5. Peer Assessment (Individual) 10%

As you can see the group project has a heavy weight on grades, try to find some reliable friends for forming a group. but from my observation most of the groups did pretty well and beyond the contents of this course.

The individual assignment is easy and answers are accessible online.

Have to mention that the final was quite easy, it has 3 parts: case questions which are qualitative, MC, and calculation questions. You probably will be able to answer most of them even without taking the course. According to my memory, the calculation questions are already covered in FINA3103.

I did not participate a lot in the course but ending with an A- is quite satisfactory.
reviews.comment_workload: The main workload goes to the project, so as mentioned find some reliable groupmates and get work done in advance.

reviews.author: honeybunch
reviews.title: interesting course, nice professor, good grade
reviews.comment_content:
1. Overview of M&A causes and consequences
2. Valuation of merger targets
3. Mergers and corporate debt
4. Going private transactions: LBO & MBO
5. Corporate restructuring, diversification, and spinoffs
6. Defensive measures against hostile takeovers
7. Group project meetings
8. Cross-border mergers and acquisitions
9. Corporate governance
11. Valuation and methods of payment in M&A
12-14. Live M&A case, Course review & Project presentations
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very chill lecture, John will ask a lot of questions for students to get participation scores. The contents are interesting.
2 lectures per week, the first lecture will be teaching out concept stuff, and the second lecture will discuss a case study relating to the concept taught that week.
reviews.comment_grading:
Project (50%): Report(30%) + Presentation(20%)
Final Exam: 30%
Participation: 20%
Final grade: A-

My project was just slightly above the mean, final exam score was not disclosed. But I think it will be fine as long as you participate fairly well during the lecture. Both verbal and chat messages (public&private) can count towards participation. Overall grading is generous.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy, but have to read one case study each week (10+ pages with a lot of appendixes).
Project accounts for half of your final grade, so make sure you find responsible teammates (max 4 ppl in a team) and be aware of time management cuz everyone would write super long for the final report. (no exact requirement, but usually ~30 pages).
Choice of the case can be narrow (e.g. a specific LBO deal) or it can be broad (e.g. M&A trends within a particular industry or country).

reviews.author: ChloéQuan
reviews.title: interest course with nice professor
reviews.comment_content:
the course material is well designed.
Pre-reading is necessary to follow the course content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
John is the chillest professor I’ve ever seen and his lecture shares the same style.
I like how he interpret students’ questions:he normally start with rationalize the question no matter how dumb it sounds and then answers it.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is pretty good. I don’t remember the exact grading scheme but project occupied a relatively huge part of it. In other words, if he likes your project, you will end up with a satisfactory final grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not very large. Participation during lecture time is not very mandatory with recordings always available online.

reviews.author: Elon Musk
reviews.title: Best finance professor I've ever met
reviews.comment_content:
The course consists of intensive case studies. If you don’t like reading cases, this course is not for you. However, if you’re like dynamic learning (like me), this course is very suitable.

Week 1: Overview of M&A
Case: Kraft

Week 2: Valuation of mergers
Case: Aqua

Week 3: M&A debt
Case: Diageo

Week 4: Going private
Case: RJR

Week 5: Corporate restructuring
Case: LAB International

Week 6: Valuation and methods of payment
no case this week

Week 7: Defensive measures
Case: Men's Wearhouse

Week 8: Corp goovernance
Case: Telefonica

Week 9: Cross-border M&A
Case: Yanzhou

Week 10: Live M&A
Case: Wine Country
reviews.comment_teaching:
Despite having the same name with the Economist John Nash, John is a great professor who makes the lecture as fun as possible. I'd say his teaching style and workload is a perfect as the Nash Equilibrium itself.

He will answer all the questions and he sometimes talks about himself. He encourages discussions and debates in class, which makes the class even more interesting. It’s a great way to learn as well as to earn participation points.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading heavily weighed on projects and presentations. You can pick your group mates as well as the topic and the company you’re going to analyse. John is quite flexible :)
The timeline is a bit tight for the project, so make sure you start once you’ve narrow down your topic.

Group Report           30%
Individual Executive summary 10%
Presentation             20%
Participation             15%
Finals                         25%
----------------------------------
Statistics:
Group Report            25/28 (mean: 24.8)
Individual Executive summary 10/10 (mean: 9.8)
Presentation              17/20 (mean: 16.3)
Participation               Not disclosed
Final                            Not disclosed

Participation is easy to get, just attend the lectures and try to be active, he'll definitely remember you.

I think I got mean in everything, probably above mean in participation, final grade B+
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fairly light, the only heavy part is the tight project timeline. Other than that, there’s no assignments and you’ll have plenty of time to prepare for finals.

reviews.author: sharon tse
reviews.comment_content:
See attached syllabus.
In summary: each week focuses on one aspect of M&A. During the week, the first class is lecture, and the second class is case study, which student read the case material (e.g. Harvard business case with supplememtary excel files on the financials) and analyse before attending. Professor lead us to solve a few relevant questions, e.g. Where are the sources of synergy from this deal? What is the best financing options for the companies in this deal?

In total, you study about 8 cases! Quite a lot for ust finance courses.
reviews.comment_teaching: Passionate teaching. Professor wants class participation, he always ask the class to answer.
reviews.comment_grading: Grade not release yet. Can't comment.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.
No midterm! Only final exam + project (with presentation).
So whether you can learn depends on self-motivation...there is no mid-term to push you to study.
